questions.question: What does the HTML abbreviation stand for, and what is its purpose?
questions.answer: HTML stands for Hypertext Markup Language. Its purpose is to structure the content of web pages using a markup language, thereby defining how browsers display information, text, and various web elements.
questions.explanation: HTML provides tags for the page, its the standard for content in various form in browser ( visual )

questions.question: What is the function of an HTML tag, and what two fundamental forms do they usually appear in?
questions.answer:
An HTML tag defines an element's beginning or end, or content itself. They generally appear in two fundamental forms: opening and closing, e.g. `

` and `

`, or a self-closing or void element, like `
`.
questions.explanation: Tag mark starting and closing part using angle brackets or empty tags itself with self-closing tags
questions.code_example:
This is Heading tag.


and self-closeing br tag

questions.question:
Explain with example, How does `
` and `` HTML elements not have end tag?
questions.answer:
The `
` (line break) and `` (image) tags are self-closing because they don't enclose content like a paragraph element, example `
` is an empty or self-closing tag as no content is present between tags for `` , content is from external resources i.e the source specified ``.
questions.explanation:
doesnt contains any content unlike block elements. Also image source file can load form any resource not inside tags but using `src`. So it need single/void type implementations to use those components.
doesnt needs content nor image tag to add another tag/ child contents as the source exist as resource

questions.question: How can text formatting be achieved through HTML and provide three specific example tags for basic text appearance changes?
questions.answer: Text formatting is achieved by applying different tags to your text elements such as `` to make the enclosed text bold (`Bold Text`), `` to make the enclosed text italic (`Italic Text`), and `` to add an underline (`Underlined Text`).
questions.explanation: Text formatting tags like b, i and u is applied over element text.
questions.code_example: Bold Text Italic Text Underlined Text

questions.question: List down HTML tags, you use for generating an HTML table structure.
questions.answer: To display data in tabular format: `<table>` tag indicates a table, `<tr>` signifies rows, `<th>` identifies header cells, and `<td>` are the actual data-containing cells within rows.
questions.explanation: Table helps to organize the elements using table like html structured parts of different properties in data table

name phone
John Doe 123

questions.question: Elaborate with examples, the key difference between the roles and purpose of HTML `element` and `tags`?
questions.answer: A tag is the markup construct used within HTML's source such as angle brackets <> that start and ends. HTML elements are containers of content usually in pair, beginning tag and an end tag surrounding it by a content. `content` span tag that acts as the wrapper and is the actual element too.
questions.explanation: Element is comprised tag name and contains between those ( usually open/closing , void with single closing ) and acts like components whereas tags mark that start or ends a view. element holds the content which have also tags.
questions.code_example: This is html text element that used p tags some inline tags with span

questions.question: In the context of HTML, briefly explain how semantic markup or coding style contributes towards meaning of content within a webpage?
questions.answer: Semantic HTML tags like `<article>`, `<aside>`, `<nav>`, `<footer>`, and `<header>` add meaning to HTML content. So, `<nav>` means its a group of navigation elements, instead of `div`, thus improving page understanding and semantics, benefiting SEO, accessibility and ease of maintainability.
questions.explanation: semantic provide clear information regarding their tags instead generic names like div and also better layout structure for web page sections.
questions.code_example: <nav> navbar item links ...</nav>   <footer> section at bottom of page... </footer> <header> Page top header section </header>

questions.question: Define, with an example, how to create an image map. What are it's basic structural requirements in terms of HTML elements?
questions.answer: Image maps allows clickable regions on the image, using the `` tag, then, `` to define clickable area, and defining `href` within those `area` tag like below example ` `
questions.explanation: Map elements provides linked elements with image ( map region ), it has map element which will holds link over areas.

questions.question: Which characters do you utilize and How to render special symbols or characters like the copyright sign, with an appropriate entity name or character code within an HTML document?
questions.answer: Special character or Symbols are rendered using HTML entity codes. For example: The entity name `©` or the numeric entity `©` can represent a copyright symbol  (©).
questions.explanation: Special char have escape sequenes in a browser like reserved and char not present inside keyboard
questions.code_example: copyright symbol using © or by ©

questions.question: With relevant elements give and an explanation about, how does an `iframe` element contributes towards displaying a webpage within an HTML document.
questions.answer: The `<iframe>` (inline frame) tag displays another HTML page within the current page. It takes an attribute `src`, which has url like `<iframe src="other_page.html" height="500px" width="600px"></iframe>` to displays an HTML page `other_page.html` within the frame.
questions.explanation: Iframes embeds one more more webpages for nested views in the html
questions.code_example: <iframe  src='otherpage.html'  width='600px' height='400px'></iframe>

questions.question: While coding and keeping things organised, specifically lists, how can code indents in the HTML file helps in clarity and readability ?
questions.answer: By aligning tags inside list structures (for instance under `<ol>` or `<ul>`) it visually separates out parts and enables clear comprehension, structure and easier to work with nested HTML element code structure.
questions.explanation: By spacing code, helps developer to clearly understands relationship between element types such as parents and nested /child hierarchy ( structure , relation, nested parts)
questions.code_example:
1. Item 1
    • item 1 a
  • item a

questions.question: Provide example demonstrating an implementation for links in a html document to be not restricted to texts and include with appropriate markup, what other element may they appear.
questions.answer: Links can appear in text such as ` text based links ` or appear over images: ` `, using an `` tag and providing destination using an `href` attribute, that wraps over the other tag (img), rather than simply in text form
questions.explanation: html text/ tag with image tags or block tag , when under a , anchor , works also a clickable button for moving between web resource in a similar method
questions.code_example: jump over target

questions.question: Define in HTML the purpose of `style sheets` or generally `css`, in terms of content structure and visual presentations?
questions.answer: A style sheet or Cascading Style Sheet(CSS), defines the visual layout, design, fonts, colors etc of an HTML content, allowing to manage consistent appearance throughout all HTML elements and maintain content presentation from document's markup.
questions.explanation: css (cascading style sheet) give a method to separate look/ style, of the page using separate rules over html structure.
questions.code_example: <style> div {background-color:lightblue}</style>

questions.question: Is creating a multicolour text on an HTML document doable?  give a demonstration or methodology that show a tag method (non recommended style usage of it), or prefer CSS implementation instead.
questions.answer: You can achieve multicoloured text either by `font` tag's color attribute: ` Text in red color Text in blue color ` (note: deprecated approach) and using preferable CSS method, i.e `text in red text in blue `
questions.code_example: text in red and blue color
questions.explanation: HTML can apply colors over texts , by html, using tag style or css styles for colors with multiple options , with diff. colours

Typically, a bullet point will take a color inherited by color setting of text, such as first text of an `li` in list `
  • List Item
` Or using more customizable `list-style-type`, `list-style-image`, with the CSS to adjust bullet color and appearance (`li{ list-style-color:red}`).
questions.code_example:

  • List item with blue
questions.explanation: Using styles in tags on parent li or specific style class on elements list items for specific colour settings

questions.question: Name four common  HTML elements in a web document that establishes a typical webpage and layouts ?
questions.answer: The common HTML layout elements are `<header>`, `<nav>`, `<main>`, `<footer>` along with `<aside>`, `<section>` `<article>`, that  help divide a web document and arrange structure based on importance and visual organization.
questions.explanation: these html element types are meant for layouts with hierarchy, (header, navbar content etc ).
questions.code_example: <header> Top Section </header><main>  Main document context <article> ...</article></main> <nav>navigation </nav> <footer> footer ... </footer>

questions.question: What does the HTML tag `<marquee>` allows the document with animated text elements in an html doc, and what can it scroll over a document?
questions.answer: The `marquee` element facilitates a webpage element scrolling behaviour. Texts or images scroll over a document (automatically), like in left-to-right, or from top-to-bottom etc using its internal markup elements(`<marquee> text/element to scroll </marquee>`)
questions.explanation: A single element , or text scrolling , based its tags.
questions.code_example: <marquee  direction='right' scrollamount='12'> Example text using Marquee, showing in horizontal way and can specify speed as attribute ( but this style of display not used )</marquee>

questions.question: With a small example give html snippet with tag and attributes to display background picture of a given page
questions.answer: To apply background-image  `<body style="background-image: url('image.jpg');">`, where the file location/url is the image. Or better use css `<body style="background-color:lightblue" class="setBackground"></body> <style> .setBackground{ background-image:url('path/image.png'); }</style>`

questions.question: Demonstrate usage of a relevant tag to insert one web page inside the other
questions.answer: An `<iframe>` facilitates embedding one HTML web page document into another document like  `  <iframe src="innerpage.html" width="800px" height="600px">  </iframe> ` , embedding a `innerpage.html`.
questions.explanation: Using `<iframe>` will help to integrate external resources (web pages) to show part view to main section on current viewed document.
questions.code_example: <iframe src='otherdoc.html' width='100%' height='600px'>

questions.question: State what characters and purpose HTML entity fulfill, for correct markup.
questions.answer: HTML entities  are special sequence of characters  which are placeholders for non keyboard chars. And are especially to show/reserve special characters to markup,  For example: the `<` can't be written directly so to render that html's code for such markup  < will be used to display that
questions.explanation: HTML entities  are special sequence of characters  which are placeholders for non keyboard chars. And are especially to show/reserve special characters to markup,  For example: the `<` can't be written directly so to render that html's code for such markup  < will be used to display that
questions.code_example: To represent < as <, > as > & as &

questions.question: Provide a reason or an explanation why a Uniform resource location string require encodings within the scope of HTML markup implementation.
questions.answer: Because URLs send info only through ASCII charset, a url contains characters out of the ASCII (Non Ascii characters), so characters not belonging in the valid URL pattern need converting (encode).  Encoded  characters,  convert invalid patterns like  `"space" or "$"`,  to "%20", or "%24" so URL's  transfers across systems will be correct.
questions.explanation: url encode allows transmitting un-transmittable string to make transmittable with browser through % character followed by hex codes.

questions.question: Does `<!DOCTYPE html>` is part of the Html's document's structural tag ? give the reason?
questions.answer: `<!DOCTYPE html>` is not an actual tag nor any  Html element  its just an declaration of document-type and has no HTML role and therefore, it does not mark-up an element.  This indicates browser to display that document under specified markup  standard or html document format .
questions.explanation: DocType will tell the version (html) of page / format and the browser uses that to show webpage and its not the content to render via such a DOCTYPE decleration tags itself rather the definition for current HTML content format.
questions.code_example: <!DOCTYPE html>

questions.question: Define using HTML syntax the Canvas Element purpose inside the html file with explanation?
questions.answer: `<canvas id="examplecanvas" height="300px" width="500px"></canvas>`, a canvas, or rectangle shape acts as container that holds graphics drawn on an HTML page with javascript by API such as by providing paths, shapes etc through a `CanvasRenderingContext2D` API that is associated with  a context (`getContext()`), making shapes visible
questions.explanation: Canvas defines a graphics display section on html using js code
questions.code_example: <canvas width=200 height=100></canvas>

questions.question: Define SVG within HTML implementation along with the structural or xml characteristics
questions.answer: Scalable Vector Graphics (SVG) are used for vector based graphics described in an XML format and its `svg` structural form starts with  `<svg> <circle></circle> ... <polygon></polygon> ...  <text> ...  </text></svg> ` format, whose shape properties defined using attributes can scale in resolution
questions.explanation: SVG draws shapes using math calculation which scales smoothly when the browser scale its views.
questions.code_example: <svg width=100 height=100> <circle  cx=50 cy=50  r=20 fill=red/></svg>

questions.question: How are <div> and <span> HTML elements similar and in what context these grouping tags used, giving real life or coding practical implementation?
questions.answer:
Both
and elements serve as generic containers. `
` is a block-level container used for sections like header, and footers and so occupies full horizontal width (`
Header/Footer block element
`) whilst `` is an inline container that groups short text like applying a background (`

this styled block of text

`) , typically using css styling on such spans, or javascript manipulation, when other semantics don't apply.

questions.question: How does IDs (unique IDs) or classes (applied on multiple html elements), differentiate in CSS with respective html attribute implementation along with selection specificator with proper naming methods, providing one usage syntax?
questions.answer:
ID, applied uniquely uses the `#` hash as selector: `#unique-heading { color:blue;}` (`

header text here

`); Class, may apply on different or multiple elements and use `.` period prefix as selector.` .red-button {background-color:red; }` (``), naming IDs use more specific identifier, classes should convey type or style (eg. 'error-box', 'left-side'.)
questions.code_example: Header section

questions.question: Provide the HTML codes how nested webpages are built with both tag implementation, and discuss, and why they would each use?
questions.answer: An embedded external webpage is achived through `<iframe>` : `<iframe src="other_page.html" width="800" height="400"</iframe>` , or embed (`<embed type="text/html" src="anotherpage.html">`), that embed another documents inside parent doc, `iframe` works in separate window space ideal for a completely new doc whereas, `embed` meant to embedded applications, or multimedia contents in main html.
questions.code_example: `<iframe src='innerhtml.html'> page loads inside </iframe>  <embed type='application/pdf' src='externalpdf.pdf'> or to a pdf external or any resources using url. if source document need be to a  non html documents / file`

questions.question: Inside the html header elements provide a list of tags and the role they accomplish for an HTML doc to enable functionalities or document related info to display page appropriately or use it for various other functions?
questions.answer: The head element acts a container of essential data of web pages, including metadata that does not show on main view content page; elements can be : `<title>`, `<meta>`, `<link>` to link CSS files `<style>`, to define CSS within header itself , base for defining base urls, and `<script>`, that contain or refer code, needed for interactivity on page ( javascript files) or web behaviour control by `<meta>` tags.
questions.code_example: <head><title> Main title</title><meta charset='utf-8'> <link rel='stylesheet' src='app.css'/>  </head>

questions.question: Elaborate what metadata is about and and what is it usage via its appropriate tag in HTML context , emphasizing it importance within html doc and for external agents?
questions.answer: Meta tags (`<meta>`) give document information such as page's description, character set (`<meta charset='utf-8'>`) viewport `<meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0">`, keywords (`<meta name="keywords" content="html,web page,web programming">`). These information help search engines with correct indexing, display settings of pages for responsive behaviour but do not directly affect the presentation of main view elements and content itself.
questions.code_example: <meta charset='utf-8'/><meta  name='viewport' content='device-width, initial-scale=1.0' ><meta name='keywords' content='html css javacsript'/>

questions.question: Elaborate an typical HTML layout how these tags and document sections used and their respective element type usage, in a web doc or website's view structure in a hierarchical perspective and use case example in markup of code?

A typical structure has these tag header at top or introduction section `

ads/ sidebar context
`, then footer section `
` always as a lower end.
questions.code_example: <header> <nav> </nav> </header><main><article></article> <aside>  </aside></main>  <footer> </footer>

questions.question: Why and what special function do we have for html entities to display non text, reserve, special characters via example implementation in doc to get accurate mark up behaviour ?
questions.answer:
HTML entities enable representation of symbols and special chars and HTML elements that browser's can recognize such as to write code as content or reserve keywords which can display properly (for e.g., display `<` ("<" less-than)), `>` (">" greater-than) so markup won't misinterpret or
. And such common ones `&` to represent ("&" and persand ). `©` represents (© Copyright sign) so such non text character can also render with proper representation.

Copyright © Reserved. Registered ® Trademarks.

questions.question: How are html's urls encoded, and why does such method enable various urls containing incompatible patterns or any special reserved character correctly?
questions.answer: URL Encoding replace non compatible and special reserved characters into safe url form with the usage of% as special marker , and follow hex digits of characters so all character can safely be transimitted (spaces become %20, dollar to %24 / becomes%2F`). Browsers use this pattern to avoid url being mistransmitted , and that make correct decoding of each reserved special character and make different OSes able to decode url as it was intened
questions.code_example: URL contains spaces/dollar those are %20,%24 for better transfer over request / communication parts for security for browsers to handle and transfer requests without corruption of data. https://exam.ple/ test/ test%20path %20 test%24%  test path / for sending to request/ server, when characters contains / $,  % as examples those requires this action as these can have some parsing behaviors

questions.question: In server communication by sending form submission, compare method that specify two approaches that define transmission pattern (GET, POST method ) in their functionality of use?
questions.answer: GET is to request or to view the resource data through URL parameters. All that URL sends becomes visible, while POST submits or adds new content or submits info to be processed to a defined resource on a web server (`<form action="" method="post">`). With Post request data becomes private unlike the URL visible GET approach as such GET request are idempotent (i.e get do not modify state in the server), whilst post typically makes changes/ adds data to data resources (it's not idempotent)
questions.code_example: <form action='serverurl.com' method='post'> Name <input /> Email:  <input/>  <input  type='submit'/></form> and using http URL (method = post sends secure body to web-servers or RESTful apis while get directly from url by querystrings. which becomes also visible, used only in specific cases. post mostly meant for action like a form for adding new or processing contents and user data securely)

questions.question: For generating complex dynamic visuals inside browser, specifically an rectangular section inside html pages. explain the usage purpose with implementation of HTML canvas to draw graphics that relies mainly on javascript support?
questions.answer: <canvas id="myCanvas" width="400" height="300"></canvas> is used along javascript drawing context APIs to allow rendering bitmap visuals using java script's 2D rendering API ( for lines, circle, paths). Example `<script> const canvas= document.getElementById("myCanvas") , const ctx = canvas.getContext('2d') ; ctx.fillRect(0, 0,100,100) </script>` that draw filled shape.
questions.code_example: <canvas id='can1' width='300' height='300'></canvas><script> const can =document.getElementById('can1');   can.getContext('2d').fillStyle='red';can.getContext('2d').fillRect(20,10,80,60) ;</script> ( Canvas works with bitmaps pixel graphics while another format using vector for its graphical implementation approach of that SVG which you will learn in later questions/ responses from this project).  it allows rendering 2D or Webgl contexts which supports pixel manipulation with html layout integration parts .  its a type rendering region.

questions.question: What HTML `<svg>` element stands for? What it provides for creation of image content (XML basis ) for usage on webpage or display and highlight advantages over other formats (like gif, jpeg formats)?
questions.answer: SVG stands for Scalable Vector Graphics. and use an xml based textual description that can scale very smoothly with no pixilation and high quality graphics are created such that you zoom, resize but does not blur and its elements also animated with great flexibility over raster or image form such jpeg orgif, allowing them being suitable for precise shapes or scalable visualisations. (pie chart diagrams, responsive icons )`<svg width="200" height="100"><circle cx="100" cy="50" r="40" fill="blue" /></svg>` to form circle shapes with text descriptions
questions.code_example: <svg  height=500px   width=400px>    <circle cx='50' cy='50' fill='orange'  r=30 /> </svg>(  you get great high-res without pixelsation so better in icon or for maps  )

questions.question: Mention and describe with one of multimedia formats and HTML implementations which a website may load, store display content related to it using appropriate types on tags and its specific behaviour or feature within browsers?
questions.answer: Multimedia such as .mp4 videos are supported on the page via `<video>` element `<video width="320" height="240" controls><source src="example_video.mp4" type="video/mp4"></video>`. and can store using the browsers storage options for access and display without online requirements in subsequent visits and is controlled by controls , it handles file types and show in correct display.
questions.code_example: <video controls  height='400' width=400'><source src='./video.mp4' type='video/mp4'>  This browser does not supports </video> ( HTML multi-media components tag type, that will handle that part )

questions.question: Using browser's feature or capabilities or javascript integration show by code usage or example of API's provided for fetching and updating location based information using available functionalities of device?
questions.answer:
The browser gives access of `navigator.geolocation` (var geo = navigator.geolocation;) . API method such as `getCurrentPosition(showPos)` retrieves latitude longitude using device's location tracking service like `

`
questions.code_example: <button onclick=" var location =  navigator.geolocation.getCurrentPosition((pos)=>{   document.write("my latitude  "+pos.coords.latitude +" my longi "+pos.coords.longitude   )   }) " >  Get Location   </button>

questions.question: Differentiate Session and local html based storage API's in its persistent scope, purpose of use and key differences between data saving across web application and specific html browser instances or session types?
questions.answer: Session storage, with it is accessible only from currently open tab and lasts till you have it open(`sessionStorage.setItem('testkey', 'value')`) local is across sessions(tab closure and opening too, `localStorage.setItem('localTestKey', 'val');`), but till browser's or OS local is cleared. session store temp context based data (form info), local is to stored preference user settings. Both allows storage using keys and values ( data strings ).
questions.code_example: <script>  sessionStorage.setItem('isLoggedIn', 'true') // single session, data removal is done  sessionStorage.removeItem() or by clear() method (for each tab ),   or window closure // other persist setting for all types localStorage.setItem('myPrefColor','#f2f2f2') ; when data must available on the user systems / devices  , until user remove explicitly using method in API's , it has methods clear ( for all localStorage.removeItem(myKey)) ( or use clear method )  </script>

questions.question: Inside HTML, with example implementation and various fields, form input handling capabilities for various common input cases or common type of usecases in various ways?
questions.answer: `<form>` contains forms , including different `<input>` tag to acquire various data type with specific attribute implementation; input type="text", or password`<input type="password" />`, or numeric`<input type="number" />`, checkboxes`<input type="checkbox" />`, or select from dropdown like `<select> <option> </option> </select>` that can collect input with their different usage attributes. (`<form action="" method="post"> <input type='text'> <input type='number'> </form>`)
questions.code_example: <form > name <input  />   email <input type=email/> <button> submit </button>   select option:   <select  ><option>option 1</option>   </select></form>  HTML parts used here.  each element, input for textual values etc have types ( attributes to HTML using name / type ) so js can validate using their key and types for form element data types in validations for form fields before  data submission.

questions.question: From fundamental design practices discuss purpose doctype, and if omitted can there be any serious implications ? explain with possible scenarios?
questions.answer: doctype is declaration to html's version (eg:`<!DOCTYPE html>`), and absence make browsers to operate on quirk mode where they do no follow specific standard so its layout will be inconsistent which will not conform a set standards . A strict DOCTYPE provides browsers follow the intended rendering for standard compliancy
questions.code_example: `<!DOCTYPE html>` HTML layout for the current file with valid HTML version will provide standardized display view across various different browsers by specific standard layouts. missing means fallback into compatibility modes, and it display might have unexpected behavior .

questions.question: Mention with proper justification a sequence of steps which are very ideal to have or use within a code implementation so a website rendering, downloading and usage gets optimized via css js link?
questions.answer: It’s usually ideal position CSS `<link>` in head, for faster first load render, before actual rendering happens , JS `<script>` right before body closing,, or with use of `<async /defer attributes`. This arrangement will also give layout style prior to render and reduce any blocking javascript operations over the body sections by only loading once body contents, visual render or images are being displayed fully with any layout styles applied

questions.question: For faster downloading and correct rendering of contents , can explain progressive rendering pattern (strategy)? and why such rendering type approach is beneficial within larger filesizes document or rich interactive websites usage ?
questions.answer: The progressive rendering helps render contents to make immediately display (instead wait full download complete ) content such image load as required or only viewports , by delaying the display. Images that can appear after text are being rendered using placeholders for them such `img loading='lazy' attribute`. Using this it make website seem interactive and available much more faster. Its advantageous in websites, large files or video streams since those content display much more quicker (like youtube thumbnails, after basic html renders, or article renders then image would appear slowly and progressively).
questions.code_example: Text content display quickly when loading on a page or when a page becomes very large to give users interactions as early possible when layout html loading. when using attribute loading= lazy from view sections, (img), where user might expect layout not showing blank ( or use progressive images format). images in the middle not above (text section should download  html elements), first , only visible region parts

questions.question: What is the difference between `canvas` and `svg`?
questions.answer: Canvas is a bitmap-based graphics element mainly for animations and complex visuals, while svg is an XML based vector graphics language, which scales well and is useful for logos, icons, and charts.
questions.code_example: Canvas - with canvas using context apis like getContext("2d").fillRec(x,y, w, h), the way it generate bitmaps that use pixels as format which has its limitation but performance for graphic animations is fast while SVG are in xml tags with  `<circle fill =red />`, `<text >svg sample</text>`, those mathematical  definition renders that,  so quality does not diminish , by rendering smoothly for high resolutions and SVG use mostly when sizes or precise drawings / diagrams is an core use case but  it performs slower when heavy pixels operation needed that use often /  during browser updates and data processing from other systems for graphical changes . ( both type are implemented in browser / layout in very separate areas / types by design from HTML or other programming platform. to create visual component / UI in different scenarios or to achieve a type or visual behaviors during various implementations)

questions.question: What is an SVG tag in HTML?

questions.question: What is the difference between `meter` and `progress` tag?
questions.answer: The `<progress>` element displays the completion progress of a task while the `<meter>` tag shows a scalar measurement within a specific range.
questions.code_example: <progress  value=75  max=100 ></progress > for completion visual type  `<meter min = 0  max=100 high=75   low = 20 value='70'> range  scale or value  </meter>` display numeric based visualization from min and maximum level parts by browser

questions.question: What does HTML5’s application cache do, and why is it necessary?
questions.answer: HTML5 application cache stores website resources locally, enabling offline access. It's a crucial component for building web applications with offline functionalities.
questions.code_example: Use a manifest in `<html manifest='app.cache'` manifest will contains a list and type or rule for which parts/resource files will cached / from the client or the server for faster view of websites that should show without issues , or without connection also. those cached layout files that enables page layout (css js fonts image , videos .. )   available locally during slow connectivity / network off mode as well . with this setup and a service worker also enabled progressive web app types functionalities too on devices / OS with a special application states too

questions.question: What does an HTML5 web worker do?
questions.answer: Web workers enable running JavaScript in the background, off the main thread, allowing for smoother UI by handling complex operations without blocking the rendering.
questions.code_example: const   test_ worker =   new  Worker(js_worker_url)  a new process started and by sending messages from current view / document, with `postMessage({})` or listeting messages through (`worker_event .onmessage(function(result))` also set `worker_event .error(  handler ()` if there an error on that task / layout . using workers helps faster html page responsiveness / user-experience since time taking intensive js / other API  operation happens separately / away main dom thread rendering. they don’t work or  access  `window` , they require to be specific context

questions.question: How to specify the metadata in HTML5?
questions.answer: Using `<meta>` tags within the `<head>` tag of the HTML page, which includes the title, author, description, and keywords.
questions.code_example: <head>  <title>Title</title> <meta name="description" content="Description"> <meta name="keywords" content="keywords"> </head>

questions.question: What are the essential goals of the HTML5 specification?
questions.answer: The primary goals of HTML5 are forward and backward compatibility, support for rich multimedia, device independence, accessibility, semantic markup, consistency, and improved security.
questions.code_example: A browser implementation of new specs follows / maintains compatibility of earlier parts along all new improvements  such that multimedia , with canvas video /audio or data, also supports assistive technologies which enhances experience,   for everyone . questions.question: What is the use of the `<output>` tag in HTML, and what are its attributes?
questions.answer: The `<output>` tag displays the results of a calculation, form or JavaScript, with attributes like for, form, and name.

</form>

questions.question: What is the difference between `<html lang=”en’>` and `<html lang=”en-US’>`?
